Complete the lines:

From around 850 BC there was a of culture. Trade got back underway in some regions. People began making from iron instead of bronze. The grew. The new were different from those of Mycenaean times. In fact, cities and their surrounding actually formed small independent . Almost none of them had . In most city-states (), the held all the chief offices. From the very beginning, however, were probably part of polis government, and the central role of the was an important characteristic of the polis.

Complete the lines:

From the end of the ninth century BC, the exploded. This meant that there was food for everyone. To resolve this problem, polis leaders founded new cities () in fertile lands. Between 750 and 55 BC, colonization led to a of Greek along the Mediterranean Sea coast. "Like frogs around a pond.", said the Athenian Plato. Major modern-day cities such as (Massalia) and (Neapolis) started out as Greek colonies. These colonies remained linked to their mother city.

Fill in the past simple.

With re-emergence of cities the Greek population (to grow). But, this (to mean) that there (to be) less food for everyone. Therefore, leaders of the citystates (to order) groups the leave the polis. The Greeks (to start) new city-states along the Mediterrenean Sea at fertile places. This development (to lead) to new trade-networks.
